intro: To render the volcano plot, start by setting dataset options below:
Choose a Platform
Choose a statistical test to compare groups. Linear Model adjusts for Age and Sex as covariates. Other methods are pairwise comparisons.
Optionally, choose an adjustment method to correct for multiple comparisons
Optionally, select Sex(es)
Optionally, select an Age Group
Optionally choose an Analyte to highlight in the Volcano Plot - if you set this, an arrow will point out the given analyte on the volcano plot
When you have set your filters, click this button to generate the volcano plot...

Volcano plots are a form of scatterplot used to indicate statistical significance                (p-value<0.05 are above the dashed line) in comparison to the fold change (upregulated analytes are to the right of the y axis)

intro: Click on any dot to choose an analyte and highlight it on the volcano plot - this will also create a boxplot showing the difference between Negative and Positive COVID-19 Status for the chosen analyte

Or, choose an analyte from this dropdown list to highlight it on the volcano plot - this will also create a boxplot showing the difference between Negative and Positive COVID-19 Status for the chosen analyte
Use these widgets to zoom, reset views, and download an SVG of the current plot.
This boxplot shows the difference between Negative and Positive COVID-19 Status for the chosen analyte
Use this widget to interact with this plot
Use the Box Select tool to select distinct sets or groups of observations - you must select at least 10 points to create a group.
Alternatively, use the Lasso Select tool to select sets or groups with finer precision
Use this widget to download a SVG of this plot
Now that you have highlighted 2 distinct groups, click here to see options to compare sets
Click this button at any point to clear the group selections from this plot

To render the correlation volcano plot, start by setting dataset options below:
1) Choose a query platform
2) Choose a query analyte. The correlation volcano plot will show correlations between this value and all other analytes from the chosen comparison platform below.
3) Choose a comparison platform.
4) When you have set all options above (steps 1 - 3), click this button to generate the correlation volcano plot...

5) Optionally choose a specific comparison analyte to highlight in the correlation volcanos plot - if you set this, an arrow will point out the given comparison analyte on the correlation volcano plot

Correlation volcano plots show correlation patterns using Spearman's Rank-Order Correlation test. The horizontal x-axis measures the strength and direction of correlations between the chosen analytes (rho). The vertical y-axis (q-value) represents the relative significance of the associations between analytes.
values to the right are positively correlated with the queried analyte
values to the left are negatively correlated with queried analyte
values above the dotted line are significantly (q < 0.1) correlated with queried analyte

intro: Click on any dot on the volcano plot to highlight a specific comparison analyte - this will generate a correlation scatter plot comparing the queried analyte and the comparison analyte.

Or, choose a specfic comparison analyte from this dropdown list to highlight it on the correlation volcano plot - this will generate a correlation scatter plot comparing the queried analyte and the comparison analyte.
Use these widgets to zoom, reset views, and download an SVG of the current plot.

This correlation plot compares record-level values from the queried analyte and the comparison analyte. Points are colored by density; the blue line represents a linear model fit with 95% confidence interval shaded in grey.
Use this widget to download a SVG of this plot
